Kenneth Stanley wrote:

>>Another difference I noticed between Markovian and non-Markovian
>>double pole balancing is that one had a bias of 1.0, the other 
>>    
>>
>0.5. 
>  
>
>>Any reason for that?
>>
>>    
>>
>
>I don't remember the reason for this (if there is one)...it may be 
>precedent...the code for DPB was initially ripped from the ESP 
>distribution that came before NEAT.
>
>In any case, one interesting point that bears on this question is 
>that we've found in NERO that high bias can effect the propertion of 
>the populatio n that does stupid things like spin in circles for no 
>apparent reason.  In general this is something you don't see when 
>you do a normal generational experiment, since you dont see everyone 
>at once, but in NERO since we saw everyone at once, we could see the 
>effect of a high bias.  One theory is that a high bias can easily 
>cause one of the turn outputs to go high with a relatively low 
>weight, making "spinniness" a likely genetic trait.  My conclusion 
>has since been to keep biases below 1.
>  
>
An interesting observation. As you say, you don't normally see what is 
going on in the vast majority of simulations, although the population 
mean fitness gives an indication of how fit the population is as a whole 
- but this figure is compilcated by many other factors such as how many 
elite are preserved per gen.

A few well defined benchmark tests would be ideal for providing harder 
evidence to back up this observation. Actually I still use a default 
weigth strength range of +-5, perhaps this range should be reduced also 
by the same reasoning?

Colin
